title: Learn SQL with Step-by-Step Visual Execution
subtitle2: Use one query inside another to solve complex problems.
cardcontent: Ananya wants to find students who scored above the class average. She uses a SUBQUERY inside the WHERE clause to compute it!
card2head: What You Will Learn from Subqueries
card2content: Understand how subqueries allow one SQL query to depend on the result of another. Learn how to calculate values like averages first, then filter records dynamically using WHERE. Subqueries are processed first, and their results are used by the main outer query.

table1.title: Calculated Class Average
table1.word: The inner query calculates the single class average mark: (85+90+78+92+88+81) / 6 = 85.67.

table2.title: All Students with Marks
table2.word: Displays every student's name and marks before filtering. Used by the outer query for comparison.

table3.title: Students Above Average
table3.code: SELECT name, marks FROM students WHERE marks > (SELECT AVG(marks) FROM students);
table3.word: The outer query filters where `marks > 85.67` (the result of the subquery).

table4.title: Students Below or Equal to Average
table4.word: Shows students whose marks are less than or equal to the class average (`<= 85.67`).
table4.code: SELECT name, marks FROM students WHERE marks <= (SELECT AVG(marks) FROM students);

multicont.word2: The subquery result is a single value (scalar subquery).
multicont.word3: The main query uses the subquery result in its WHERE clause.
multicont.word4: Subqueries can also be used in the FROM or SELECT clauses.
multicont.word5:
